page.title: 07PIG FARMING
page.content: PIG FARMING IS NOT PRACTISED ON A LARGE SCALE IN THIS AREA BUT AS A SIDELINE TO MAIN FARMING ACTIVITIES. A TYPICAL PIG UNIT ONLY CONTAINS 25 TO 30 SOWS AND 2 BOARS. THE MAIN BREEDS ENCOUNTERED ARE GLOUCESTER OLD SPOTS, SADDLEBACKS, AND THE RARE BERKSHIRES ALTHOUGH THE LARGE WHITE IS BETTER FOR MEAT. THE AVERAGE LITTER IS 13 BUT AT 4 TO 5 YEARS, THE SOWS PRODUCE LESS PIGLETS AND ARE SLAUGHTERED FOR HAM AND PIES. THE AVERAGE WEIGHT OF A FULLY GROWN SOW IS 150 KILOS. PIGLETS ARE EITHER SOLD AT 4 TO 6 WEEKS TO OTHER FARMS FOR BREEDING OR FATTENING OR SOLD FOR PORK AT 4 MONTHS. PIGS ARE PRONE TO OVER 100 DISEASES, ALL VERY INFECTIOUS. FARMERS COMPLAIN THAT PIG FARMING IS NOT VERY PROFITABLE DUE TO THE HIGH COST OF PIG FOOD AND THE LOW PRICE OF PORK. E.G. 28 SOWS ONLY BRING IN A PROFIT OF Â£500.00 PER YEAR.
